folder: Union Square & 4th Avenue & Between 14th and 15th Streets & [George Washington Statue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Union Square: Shows the east side of the Square (4th Avenue), between 14th and 15th Street and the George Washington Statue.
1860

(2) North over 4th Avenue from 14th Street, note, the Everett House to the left of the Statue; it is at 17th Street.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 4th Avenue - Between 14th and 15th Streets - [George Washington Statue.]

title: Manhattan: Union Square - 4th Avenue - Between 14th and 15th Streets - [George Washington Statue.]

text:
Fourth Avenue, west side, south from East 14th Street, showing the I, R. T. Subway under construction.

April 2, 1901

Board of Transportation photograph
William B. Parsons Collection

107, 109, 111 East 14th Street, north side, east of Fourth Avenue.  No. 109, in the center, is old Steinway Hall.

June, 1925

14th Street, north side, east from Fourth Avenue (Union Square): new Consolidated Gas Building at Irving Place.

August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

S. E. corner of Fourth Avenue and 14th Street.
Note Blue Eagle N. R. A. posters in windows; this was in early days of N. R. A., when it received enthusiastic, even hysterical, support.
Note also election poster for Tammany ticket in Mayoralty campaign.
This photograph was made on Election Day, when a reform ticket was elected.

November 7, 1933.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

101-103 East 14th Street at N.E. corner of Union Square East (Fourth Avenue).

June 5, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Fourth Ave., east side, south from East 14th to 11th Streets. On the extreme left appears a portion of the Central Savings Bank Building at the S.E. corner of East 14th Street.

June 11, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

(1)

East 14th Street, south side, east from (No. 108), but not including Fourth Ave., and showing the City Theatre at No. 114, a motion picture house.

August 11, 1936.

P. L. Sperr

(2)

The same.

September 10, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

East 14th Street, south side, east from (No. 108), but not including Fourth Ave., and showing the City Theatre at No. 114, a motion picture house.

August 11, 1936.

P. L. Sperr

(2)

The same.

September 10, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
